Lab: Derivatives in Context – Deep Applications of Product & Quotient Rules

1. Function and its Derivative graphs

Let:

f(x)=ex+1ex+x3f(x) = e^x + \frac{1}{e^x} + x^3 f(x)=ex+ex1​+x3

Step-by-Step Instructions

1. Find the derivative f′(x)f'(x)f′(x).

2. Use GeoGebra to plot f(x)f(x)f(x) and f′(x)f'(x)f′(x).

3. Find the critical points of f(x)f(x)f(x) by solving f′(x)=0f'(x) = 0f′(x)=0. (What are the x values for which f′(x)=0f'(x) = 0f′(x)=0?)

4. Determine the local maxima and minima of f(x)f(x)f(x).

5. Determine the sign of f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) in each interval divided by those points. (Whether f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) is positive or negative in each interval decided by the critical points?)

6. Determine the intervals on which f(x)f(x)f(x) is increasing or decreasing. (Hint: can you see the connection between the sign of f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) and the increasing/decreasing intervals?)

  • Observe the graphs of f(x)f(x)f(x) and f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) to get answers and intuition for the questions above.

2. Server Load Model

A server handles incoming data packets. The incoming data rate (in packets/sec) is modeled as:

f(t)=(5t+1)(e−t)f(t) = (5t + 1)(e^{-t}) f(t)=(5t+1)(e−t)

where ttt is time in seconds.

Tasks:

1. Compute f′(t)f'(t)f′(t) using the product rule.

2. Interpret the meaning of f′(2)f'(2)f′(2). Is the load increasing or decreasing at this moment?

3. Use GeoGebra to plot f(t)f(t)f(t) and f′(t)f'(t)f′(t) on the same axes.

4. Mark local max/min and points where f′(t)=0f'(t) = 0f′(t)=0.

5. Relate these turning points to real-world server behavior (e.g. peak load time, diminishing usage).

3. Pollution Density in a River

The concentration of a pollutant at a certain downstream point is modeled by:

C(t)=100tt2+1C(t) = \frac{100t}{t^2 + 1} C(t)=t2+1100t​

where C(t)C(t)C(t) is the concentration (in ppm) at time ttt hours.

Tasks:

1. Use the quotient rule to find C′(t)C'(t)C′(t).

2. Simplify the derivative and determine when the concentration is increasing or decreasing.

3. Find the time ttt when the concentration is at its maximum.

4. Explain why this makes sense physically (e.g. build-up vs. dilution of the pollutant over time).

4. Cooling of a Beverage

You take a hot drink outside in the winter. Its temperature (in °C) is modeled by:

T(t)=100+10tt+2T(t) = \frac{100 + 10t}{t + 2} T(t)=t+2100+10t​

where ttt is time in minutes after exposure.

Tasks:

  • Compute T′(t)T'(t)T′(t) using the quotient rule.
  • Use GeoGebra to plot T(t)T(t)T(t) and T′(t)T'(t)T′(t) on the same axes.

Label:

  • Points where ∣T′(t)∣|T'(t)|∣T′(t)∣ is large (i.e. the drink is cooling fastest).
  • Points where T′(t)≈0T'(t) \approx 0T′(t)≈0 (i.e. cooling has slowed down).

Answer:

1. At what time is the drink cooling fastest? Why?

2. What does it mean when T′(t)→0T'(t) \to 0T′(t)→0? Is this realistic?
